Item#:
 
8256




















Level5
















Containment Class:


esoteric






Secondary Class:


uncontained








Disruption Class:


amida






Risk Class:


notice








link to memo




































Threat Level:
 Black




Special Containment Procedures and Description








A 2-hour long exposure image of SCP-8256 taken using the ████ Foundation telescope.








Special Containment Procedures:


Due to the distance, size and nature of 
SCP-8256
 containment is currently considered impossible. Instead, Foundation efforts focus on disinformation campaigns in both the public and academic spheres, discrediting any reports of either 'disappearing' or 'reappearing' galaxies as either hoaxes or photography errors with parties involved being administered Class A amnestics. Foundation WebCrawler 8256, nicknamed the, "
Galactic Hunter
", is tasked with monitoring online astronomical and astrophotography groups and forums for references made to 
SCP-8256
, with any media related to 
SCP-8256
 being deleted, with associated individuals administered an amnestic via an anti-memetic screen message. Foundation agents embedded in national space agencies and academic institutions are to discourage the study of sky where 
SCP-8256
 is located and are to manually edit 
SCP-8256
 out of any photographs or videos before publication of scientific material.


SCP-8256
 is currently monitored weekly
1
 by Sr Researcher Sarah Broder at 
Site-12
's astrophysics department, with any major visual or structural changes to be immediately reported to Site 12's site director. Should an Almada event occur O5-█, Dr Williams, NASA and the ESA are to be immediately contacted, with a relevant cover story released to the public if required.


Description:






Current location of 
SCP-8256
, (indicated by the small red dot).






SCP-8256
 is an intermediate spiral galaxy, measuring approximately 24,000ly across and 2000ly in thickness
2
, currently located approximately 116 (± 4.7mly) from Earth in the 
Columba
 constellation, (0.4° north-east of γ
3
 Columbae). The object has an Apparent magnitude of 12.72 (± 1.1V) with no other apparent anomalous physical characteristics that would set it apart from other non-anomalous spiral galaxies typically found in nature. SCP-8256 consists of four massive spiral arms. predominantly blue, pink, and white, surrounding a bright galactic core with an estimate number of 100 billion stars (±5 billion) . At its centre lies a supermassive black hole with an estimated mass of 2.5 million solar masses.


SCP-8256's
 primary anomalous property is that no biological organism is capable of viewing it through a telescope, binoculars or any other optical instrument, regardless of the optical size of the instrument, (see experiment logs). Instead observers will simply see a regular patch of sky, filled with an average amount of stars. However, this effect does not extend to photographs or videos of 
SCP-8256
 with viewers initially able to view the object for 5 - 10 seconds, until 
SCP-8256's
 second primary anomalous effect will manifest. This will cause the individual (hereby designated 
SCP-8256-A
), to become unable to view any photos or videos of 
SCP-8256
, for a certain period of time. Describing that these appear blurry, nonsensical or simply aren't visible and appear as either blank white or black. Notably, this perceptual anomaly is not universal. Unaffected observers can view images and footage of 
SCP-8256
 without issue, and written descriptions, data, and measurements related to 
SCP-8256
 remain legible to all individuals, including 
SCP-8256-A
.


The third anomalous property of 
SCP-8256
, is that individuals who has observed 
SCP-8256
 will slowly over a period of between 30 minutes and 2 hours forget the physical description of the object, nor will they be able to describe what 
SCP-8256
 looks like. However, this does not affect data or information of 
SCP-8256
, as individuals will still be able to recall how large the galaxy is, amount of stars or other numerical values.


Almada Events:

Due to reasons currently unknown 
SCP-8256
 is capable of spontaneous dematerialization and rematerialization in space, often moving 10's of millions of light years instantly. These events, are proceeded by a sudden increase in X-ray radiation emissions from SCP-8256 for 49 - 120 seconds. Both these events and the new location of SCP-8256 appear to be random, (refer to File-8256 Revision: 26/12/90, File-8256 Revision: 28/08/99 and Incident-8256-4), with no apparent pattern or visible related variables between manifestations. Subsequent investigation of regions affected by Almada events utilizing 
SCP-2154
 has revealed a higher amount of X-ray, microwave and infrared radiation, as well as a noticeable decrease of stars and an increase of nebulous activity.




Experimentation and Discovery


Experiment logs of SCP-8256




+ Initial observation experiments with SCP-8256




- Close








Initial Observation Experiment 1








Subject


D8256-A






Events




DXXXX-A was ordered to attempt to view 
SCP-8256
 through three separate telescopes:




A 12' Dobsonian-Newtonian telescope


A 8' Refractor telescope


SCP ██████ Lunar Telescope










Results


As expected, D8256-A was unable to view SCP-8256 and described seeing a normal amount of stars in all telescopes.












Initial Observation Experiment 2








Subjects


Chimpanzees: "Bella", "Ham" and "Max"






Background


Under Foundation biological researcher Dr Mitchell, three chimpanzee's were trained to be able to identify spiral galaxies through the process of a reward system upon pressing a button if one was identified. This was done to identify if non-human animals were able to view 
SCP-8256
.






Events




Bella, Ham and Max were ordered to attempt to view 
SCP-8256
 through two separate telescopes:




A 12' Dobsonian-Newtonian telescope


A 8' Refractor telescope










Results


None of the three chimpanzees pressed the button and it was assumed that they were not able to see 
SCP-8256
.












Initial Observation Experiment 3








Subject


Astronomical Anomalous Detection and Tracking Software (AADT)






Background


Developed in 1987 the Astronomical Anomalous Detection and Tracking Software (AADT) was an artifical intelligence developed by the Foundation for both the detection and tracking of anomalies beyond the Earth. The goal of this experiment was to determine if non-living beings were capable of viewing 
SCP-8256
.






Events




The AADT was given a non-exposure camera feed of 
SCP-8256
 using the following three telescopes:




A 12' Dobsonian-Newtonian telescope


A 8' Refractor telescope


SCP ██████ Lunar Telescope




The AADT was tasked to both identify if a galaxy was present and to describe the object to the researchers.








Results


The AADT was both able to identify that a spiral galaxy was present and was able to describe it's relative brightness and magnitude. This confirmed the hypothesis that 
SCP-8256
 is visible to non-biological organisms.






_






Initial Observation Experiment 4








Subject


SCP-2154






Background


Handled by Sr Researcher Sarah Broder, 
SCP-2154
 was utilized to determine whether anomalous objects were immune to the effect of 
SCP-8256
 and if they could be used for more reliable and accurate study of the object.






Events


Researcher Sarah Broder using 
SCP-2154
 directed the anomaly towards the region of sky where 
SCP-8256
 is located and reported seeing [DATA EXPUNGED].






Results


[DATA EXPUNGED]












Discovery and Identification


SCP-8256
 was first discovered by NASA and the European Space Agency (ESA) following the launch of the 
Hubble Space Telescope
 in May 1990 after reports of NASA and ESA personnel being unable to properly identify an anomalous object within telescope images.


A Foundation investigation was initiated in early July 1990 after a leaked image containing SCP-8256 surfaced publicly (designated Incident-8256-1). This led to the official identification 
SCP-8256
. All affected NASA and ESA personnel were administered Class-A amnestics, and a cover story was disseminated, attributing the leaked image to digital manipulation by an unidentified group.


Following Incident-8256-1 and further study of 
SCP-8256
, in 1991 study of 
SCP-8256
 was transferred over to the Foundation and an agreement between NASA, ESA and the Foundation allowed for embedded agents to prevent further study of 
SCP-8256
 by the agencies.








+ Incident-8256-2




- Close










STS-38 in Low Earth Orbit after deployment of Foundation Orbital Telescope Lunar Watch.








Incident-8256-2






Location of 
SCP-8256
 from 02:32 to 03:32 following Incident-8256-2 on December 25th, 1990 (indicated by the small red dot).






At approximately 02:32 (GMT) on December 25th, 1990, the Foundation’s lunar orbital telescope, 
Lunar Watch
, reported an anomaly regarding 
SCP-8256
. For one hour, the object had seemingly teleported from its known position near β Crucis in the Crux constellation to 0.8° west of β Andromedae in the Andromeda constellation before returning to its original location sixty minutes later. Additionally, 
SCP-8256
 moved approximately 27 million light-years closer to Earth, with its apparent magnitude increasing from 12.72 to 11.64, making it significantly brighter and more visible to both space-based and terrestrial telescopes. However, due to the timing and duration of the event, no cover story was required, and since no personnel from established space agencies observed the anomaly, amnestics were deemed unnecessary.






NOTICE FROM THE FOUNDATION ANOMALOUS ASTROPHYSICS RESEARCH DEPARTMENT


Following yesterday's event (which we have cataloged as 
Incident-8256-2
 for simplicity’s sake), the apparent risk posed by 
SCP-8256
 has, at least in my view, increased drastically. Even if this thing miraculously never teleports, dematerializes, or whatever you want to call it again, the mere fact that it 
can
 do so should not be understated. We cannot contain an entire galaxy, for goodness' sake. And what if this thing were to manifest in a more dangerous location? We risk both the Foundation’s secrecy and public safety. If 
SCP-8256
 were to materialize near or even inside the Milky Way, the consequences would be catastrophic. For these reasons, I propose reclassifying the object to Keter and formally notifying both NASA and the ESA of the 8256 incident next month in █████.


— J Williams, head of Site 12's Astrophysics department, December 26th, 1990.

File-8256 Revision: 14/01/91

 Yellow


Special Containment Procedures:






Meeting between O5-█, NASA Administrator Richard H. Truly and ESA officials following Incident-8256-1 (1991).






Due to the distance, size and nature of 
SCP-8256
 containment is currently considered impossible. Instead, Foundation efforts focus on disinformation campaigns in both the public and academic spheres, discrediting any reports of either 'disappearing' or 'reappearing' galaxies as either hoaxes or photography errors with parties involved being administered Class A amnestics. 
SCP-8256
 is currently monitored weekly at Site-12's astrophysics department, with any major visual or structural changes to be immediately reported to Site 12's site director.


Revised Special Containment Procedures:

Due to the distance, size and nature of 
SCP-8256
 containment is currently considered impossible. Instead, Foundation efforts focus on disinformation campaigns in both the public and academic spheres, discrediting any reports of either 'disappearing' or 'reappearing' galaxies as either hoaxes or photography errors with parties involved being administered Class A amnestics. 
SCP-8256
 is currently monitored weekly at Site-12's astrophysics department, with any major visual or structural changes to be immediately reported to Site 12's site director.


Following an agreement between the Overseer Council, NASA Administrator, Richard H. Truly and representatives from the European Space Agency, (whom had both classified SCP-8256 as 
Anomalous Object 1990G
 since Incident-8256-1). All affairs related to 
SCP-8256
 is to be monitored by the Foundation, with both tracking and scientific monitoring of the object to be performed by the Foundation lunar orbital telescope, 
Lunar Watch
. Foundation agents currently embedded in both NASA and the ESA are to discourage the study of sky where 
SCP-8256
 is located and are to manually edit 
SCP-8256
 out of any photographs or videos before publication of scientific material.






NOTICE FROM THE FOUNDATION ANOMALOUS ASTROPHYSICS RESEARCH DEPARTMENT


Following yesterday's agreement between the O5s, NASA, and the ESA in █████, I am rather disappointed. While we were able to transfer the study of 
SCP-8256
 to the Foundation, I fear the higher-ups aren't taking the apparent threat of 
SCP-8256
 into proper consideration, nor are they willing to reclassify the object from Euclid to Keter - but I digress. As far as I am aware, NASA and the ESA were made aware (mostly due to my pleading with the Council) of Incident-8256-2. Additionally, the Foundation plans to use the telescope launched last year aboard the shuttle to monitor 
SCP-8256
, which hopefully should allow us to monitor this thing better and understand it.


— J Williams, head of Site 12's Astrophysics Department, January 14th, 1991.














+ File-8256 Revision: 28/08/99




- Close










Location of SCP-8256 since August 27th, 1999 (17:55) following Incident-8256-3 (indicated by the small red dot).








File-8256 Revision: 28/08/99








Item#:
 
8256




















Level5
















Containment Class:


keter






Secondary Class:


{$secondary-class}








Disruption Class:


ekhi






Risk Class:


notice








link to memo




































Threat Level:
 Red






NOTICE FROM OVERSEER COMMAND


Following yesterday’s event (which we have classified as Incident-8256-3), the unprecedented danger posed by 
SCP-8256
 has become clear to the Foundation. What we initially believed to be a simple anti-memetic celestial object has proven to be something far worse. I, along with many members of the Council, agree with Dr. Williams’s assessment and have formally reclassified 
SCP-8256
 from Euclid to Keter. Never before have we encountered an object of such size and nature, 
SCP-8256
 possesses both the capacity to shatter the veil of Foundation secrecy and to bring about the destruction of Earth and humanity along with it.

— O5-█, 28th of August, 1999.






Revised Special Containment Procedures:


Due to the distance, size and nature of SCP-8256 containment is currently considered impossible. Instead, Foundation efforts focus on disinformation campaigns in both the public and academic spheres, discrediting any reports of either 'disappearing' or 'reappearing' galaxies as either hoaxes or photography errors with parties involved being administered Class A amnestics. SCP-8256 is currently monitored weekly at Site-12's astrophysics department, with any major visual or structural changes to be immediately reported to Site 12's site director.


Following an agreement between the Overseer Council, NASA Administrator, Richard H. Truly and representatives from the European Space Agency, (whom had both classified SCP-8256 as Anomalous Object 1990G since Incident-8256-1). All affairs related to SCP-8256 is to be monitored by the Foundation, with both tracking and scientific monitoring of the object to be performed by the Foundation lunar orbital telescope, Lunar Watch. Foundation agents currently embedded in both NASA and the ESA are to discourage the study of sky where SCP-8256 is located and are to manually edit SCP-8256 out of any photographs or videos before publication of scientific material.


Should an 
Almada
 event occur, both NASA and the European Space Agency are to be made aware,
4
with a relevant cover story released to the public describing 
SCP-8256
 to simply be an unusual reflection of nearby astronomical objects caused by a large dust cloud.








X-ray image of 
SCP-8256
 moments before Incident-8256-3, the first 
Almada
 Event.








Almada Event:

Incident-8256-3 (classified as an 
Almada
 Event) refers to an event involving 
SCP-8256
. On August 27, 1999, at approximately 17:54, Foundation telescope 
Lunar Watch
 reported a sudden and significant increase in X-ray radiation from 
SCP-8256
, with emissions reaching approximately 6–7 times its normal baseline rate for an estimated 49 seconds. Following this, 
SCP-8256
 permanently dematerialized from its known location near β Crucis in the 
Crux
 constellation, subsequently rematerializing at a new location, 0.2° east of τ
5
 Piscis Austrini in the 
Piscis Austrinus
 constellation. A follow-up investigation at Site-12 indicated that 
SCP-8256
's apparent magnitude had decreased from 11.64 to 12.66, and its distance from Earth had increased by approximately 40.1 million light-years.










+ File-8256 Revision: 7/05/04




- Close




File-8256 Revision: 7/05/04






NOTICE FROM THE FOUNDATION ANOMALOUS ASTROPHYSICS RESEARCH DEPARTMENT


As you are aware we had another event concerning 
SCP-8256
 roughly 48 hours ago, I alongside the rest of the researchers here at Site-12 have been in panic mode, trying to figure out what is causing what we have deemed an Almada Event to occur. To my knowledge, O5-█ alongside ██████ are in an emergency meeting with both NASA and the ESA trying to figure out what has just happened. Due to the simple fact that we have no idea where the hell it is, and our telescopes have had no luck locating it, for now we are assuming 
SCP-8256
 has either completely vanished from reality, has dematerialised on the other side of the universe or is intentionally hiding from us and we have considered it lost.


— J Williams, head of Site 12's Astrophysics Department, May 7th, 2004.












Item#:
 
8256




















Level5
















Containment Class:


esoteric






Secondary Class:


uncontained








Disruption Class:


amida






Risk Class:


notice








link to memo




































Threat Level:
 Black


Revised Special Containment Procedures:

Due to the distance, size and nature of 
SCP-8256
 containment is currently considered impossible. Instead, Foundation efforts focus on disinformation campaigns in both the public and academic spheres, discrediting any reports of either 'disappearing' or 'reappearing' galaxies as either hoaxes or photography errors with parties involved being administered Class A amnestics. Foundation WebCrawler 8256, nicknamed the, "
Galactic Hunter
", is tasked with monitoring online astronomical and astrophotography groups and forums for references made to 
SCP-8256
, with any media related to 
SCP-8256
 being deleted, with associated individuals administered an amnestic via an anti-memetic screen message. Foundation agents embedded in national space agencies and academic institutions are to discourage the study of sky where 
SCP-8256
 is located and are to manually edit 
SCP-8256
 out of any photographs or videos before publication of scientific material.


SCP-8256
 is currently monitored weekly by Sr Researcher Sarah Broder at Site-12's astrophysics department, with any major visual or structural changes to be immediately reported to Site 12's site director. Should an Almada event occur O5-█, Dr Edwards, NASA, ESA and The China National Space Administration are to be immediately contacted, with a relevant cover story released to the public if required.


Revised Description:

SCP-8256 is an intermediate spiral galaxy, measuring approximately 24,000ly across and 2000ly in thickness, currently located an unknown distance from Earth. The object last had an Apparent magnitude of 12.66 with no other apparent anomalous physical characteristics that would set it apart from other non-anomalous spiral galaxies typically found in nature. SCP-8256 consists of four massive spiral arms. predominantly blue, pink, and white, surrounding a bright galactic core with an estimate number of 100 billion stars (±5 billion) . At its centre lies a supermassive black hole with an estimated mass of 2.5 million solar masses.


SCP-8256's primary anomalous property is that no biological organism is capable of viewing it through a telescope, binoculars or any other optical instrument, regardless of the optical size of the instrument, (see experiment logs). Instead observers will simply see a regular patch of sky, filled with an average amount of stars. However, this effect does not extend to photographs or videos of SCP-8256 with viewers initially able to view the object for 5 - 10 seconds, until SCP-8256's second primary anomalous effect will manifest. This will cause the individual (hereby designated SCP-8256-A), to become unable to view any photos or videos of SCP-8256, for a certain period of time.4 Describing that these appear blurry, nonsensical or simply aren't visible and appear as either blank white or black. Notably, this perceptual anomaly is not universal. Unaffected observers can view images and footage of SCP-8256 without issue, and written descriptions, data, and measurements related to SCP-8256 remain legible to all individuals, including SCP-8256-A.


The third anomalous property of SCP-8256, is that individuals who has observed SCP-8256 will slowly over a period of between 30 minutes and 2 hours forget the physical description of the object, nor will they be able to describe what SCP-8256 looks like. However, this does not affect data or information of SCP-8256, as individuals will still be able to recall how large the galaxy is, amount of stars or other numerical values.


Almada Events:

Due to reasons currently unknown 
SCP-8256
 is capable of spontaneous dematerialization and rematerialization in space, often moving 10's of millions of light years instantly. These events, are proceeded by a sudden increase in X-ray radiation emissions from 
SCP-8256
 for 49 - 120 seconds. Both these events and the new location of 
SCP-8256
 appear to be random, (refer to both File-8256 Revision: 26/12/90 and File-8256 Revision: 28/08/99), with apparent pattern or visible related variables between manifestations. Subsequent investigation of regions affected by Almada events utilizing 
SCP-2154
 has revealed a higher amount of X-ray, microwave and infrared radiation, as well as a noticeable decrease of stars and an increase of nebulous activity. Following










      ⤷ +Incident-8256-4




- Hide whatever










O5-█ alongside ██████ speaking with representatives from NASA and the ESA in the aftermath of Incident-8256-4.






Incident-8256-4


Incident-8256-4 refers to an event involving 
SCP-8256
. At 23:27 on May 5, 2004, 
SCP-8256
 permanently dematerialized from its known location near τ Piscis Austrini in the 
Piscis Austrinus
 constellation, relocating to an as-yet unknown location. Similar to previous Almada events, a sudden, significant increase in X-ray radiation from the region of 
SCP-8256
 was detected for 120 seconds before the event. A subsequent investigation by the ESA and the Foundation into the τ Piscis Austrini region revealed elevated levels of X-ray, microwave, and infrared radiation.


Due to a major astronomy event occurring at the time, an estimated 30,000 civilians witnessed and photographed both Incident-8256-4 and 
SCP-8256
, with a further 750,000 people becoming aware of the event online in numerous astronomy and astrophotography groups. In response, a cover story involving a large-scale computer glitch and deliberate media manipulation by a troll group was disseminated. All direct witnesses were administered Class-A amnestics, and all online material was expunged from the internet, with the object being both reclassified from Keter to Uncontained and it's threat level being classified to Black.


Following the aftermath of Incident-8256-4 and the threat 
SCP-8256
 posed to both normalcy and Foundation secrecy, Foundation WebCrawler-8256, nicknamed "
Galactic Hunter
", was developed and deployed. Its purpose is to monitor media for references to 
SCP-8256
 and to track reports of disappearing or reappearing galaxies, aiding both in suppressing public awareness of 
SCP-8256
 and in determining its new location upon its next manifestation.










+ Incident-8256-5




- Close






Incident-8256-5


Incident-8256-5 refers to an event involving 
SCP-8256
 and subsequently the current location of 
SCP-8256
. At 07:17 on March 22, 2012, Foundation telescope, 
Lunar Watch
, detected that 
SCP-8256
 rematerialized approximately 0.4° north-east of γ Columbae in the Columba constellation, (116mly away from the Earth). Unlike previous manifestations a large amount of X-ray radiation was detected 
before
 manifestation, (approximately 4 times the baseline rate). However, unlike previous Almada events, both the region surrounding 
SCP-8256
 and the object it's self has had an ongoing above normal amount of X-ray radiation,(approximately 2 - 2.5 times the baseline rate). An investigation into this has been launched to determine both the effects on the surrounding space and the threat posed to Earth.


In response to Incident-8256-5, a secondary media cover story was issued, citing the phenomenon as the result of an unprecedented event involving an unknown X-ray emission source. Similar to previous incidents, all direct witnesses were administered Class-A amnestics, and all online material relating to the incident was scrubbed from public access.

. Tau
